reviewer.summary: Review questions focused on web session concepts, session ID security, and cookie attributes.

quiz.question: The session ID is temporarily equivalent to the strongest authentication method used by the application.
Session ID entropy refers to the degree of predictability.
Web applications should not use cookies for session ID exchange management.
The session ID is assigned at session creation time.
The session ID name should be extremely descriptive.
Why should the session ID content/value be meaningless?
options: To make it easier to remember

quiz.question: What is a session identifier also known as?
What is a web session?
options: A sequence of network HTTP request and response transactions associated with the same user
quiz.answer: A sequence of network HTTP request and response transactions associated with the same user

quiz.question: What is one of the primary purposes of web sessions?
options: To prevent users from accessing a web application
To design the layout of a web page
To retain information or status about each user for the duration of multiple requests
To speed up server response times
quiz.answer: To retain information or status about each user for the duration of multiple requests

quiz.question: Which of the following best describes session management?
options: A technique for designing web pages.
A method for encrypting data transmissions.
A process by which a server maintains the state of an entity interacting with it.
A process of managing user interface elements.
quiz.answer: A process by which a server maintains the state of an entity interacting with it.

quiz.question: What does the HttpOnly attribute instruct web browsers not to allow?
options: Access to the cookies via the DOM (document.cookie) object by scripts
The cookie to be sent over HTTPS
The user to delete the cookie
quiz.answer: Access to the cookies via the DOM (document.cookie) object by scripts

quiz.question: What kind of connection is recommended to protect the session ID exchange?
In Session ID Generation and Verification, what does the "Strict" mechanism enforce?
options: The web application will only accept session ID values that have been previously generated by the web application.
The web application will initially accept any session ID value set by the user.
quiz.answer: The web application will only accept session ID values that have been previously generated by the web application.

quiz.question: What does the Domain attribute in a cookie instruct web browsers to do?
options: To display the cookie to the user
To only send the cookie to the specified domain and all subdomains
To delete the cookie after use
quiz.answer: To only send the cookie to the specified domain and all subdomains

quiz.question: When is the session ID included in the context of HTTP requests?
What can a session ID disclose if not properly renamed?
options: Technologies and programming languages used by the web application
quiz.answer: Technologies and programming languages used by the web application

quiz.question: To keep the authenticated state, web applications provide users with a:
What should a web application use for session ID exchange management?
For how long is the session ID shared and exchanged by the user and the web application?
options: Until the user closes the browser
For the duration of the session
quiz.answer: For the duration of the session

quiz.question: What does the Path attribute in a cookie instruct web browsers to do?
options: To only send the cookie to the specified directory or subdirectories
To limit the size of the cookie
To hide the cookie from the user
To save the cookie in a specific location
quiz.answer: To only send the cookie to the specified directory or subdirectories

quiz.question: Refer to the given cookie: Which statement best describes how this cookie is being handled by the browser? (Missing Image Context)
options: Ensures the cookie is only sent over HTTPS, protecting it from man-in-the-middle attacks
Stores user preferences and remembers them across sessions
Combines both Secure and HttpOnly attributes for maximum protection against both MitM and XSS attacks
Prevents JavaScript from accessing the cookie, mitigating cross-site scripting (XSS) attacks
quiz.answer: Requires image context to determine exact attribute.

quiz.question: Which statement best describes how this cookie is being handled by the browser? (Missing Image Context)
options: The cookie can be used in any path inside chromewebstore.google.com
The cookie can be used inside chromewebstore.google.com/detail/images
The cookie cannot be used inside chromewebstore.google.com/detail/images
The cookie cannot be used inside chromewebstore.google.com/detail/cookie-editor
quiz.answer: Requires image context to determine exact attribute.
